title: 104_hr3389
content:
The Act titled "District of Columbia Pension Liability Funding Reform Act of 1996" increases and extends the federal contribution to District of Columbia pension funds. The District of Columbia Retirement Reform Act amends section 144(a) by adjusting the funding amounts for the pension fund from fiscal year 1996 to 2036. The District of Columbia Retirement Reform Act adjusts funding amounts for the pension fund from fiscal year 1996 to 2036, with specific sums allocated for each fiscal year. The District of Columbia Retirement Reform Act is amended to change the years from 2004 to 2036 in various sections, including funding amounts for the pension fund. The District of Columbia Retirement Reform Act is amended to change the years from 2004 to 2036 in various sections, including funding amounts for the pension fund. In section 162(d) (sec. 1-732(d)(1), D.C. Code), paragraph (5) is removed. TITLE II--CHANGES IN RETIREMENT BENEFITS

Subtitle A--Police Officers' and Fire Fighters' Contribution

SEC. 201. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION.

Amends the Policemen and Firemen's Retirement and Disability Act to increase the contribution percentage for members who are officers or members of the Metropolitan Police force or the Fire Department of the District of Columbia.

SEC. 202. ESTABLISHMENT OF SINGLE ANNUAL COST-OF-LIVING ADJUSTMENT. Amendment to subsection (m) of the Policemen and Firemen's Retirement and Disability Act involves the Mayor determining the annual change in the price index for adjustments to annuities. If there is a rise in the price index, annuities with a commencing date on or before September 1 of the year will be affected. An annuity with a commencing date on or before September 1 of the year will be increased based on the percentage change computed under paragraph (2), adjusted to the nearest 1/10 of 1 percent. For annuities starting after September 1 of the preceding year, a pro rata increase will be calculated based on the percentage change multiplied by the number of months the annuity was payable before the effective date of the increase, not exceeding 12 months. The increase in annuity payments is based on the percentage change adjusted to the nearest 1/10 of 1 percent. SEC. 203. EQUALIZATION OF CONTRIBUTION RULES FOR FORMER RETIREES. Amends retirement laws for former retirees. Repeals relief allowance or compensation increase for police and firemen. Subtitle B focuses on teachers' contributions, increasing it to 8 percent from October 1, 1996. Establishes a single annual cost-of-living adjustment. Section 21(b) of the Act for the retirement of public-school teachers in the District of Columbia is amended to change the process for determining the annual cost-of-living adjustment. The Mayor will now calculate the percentage change in the price index for the preceding year to determine if there is a rise in the index. The annual cost-of-living adjustment for public-school teachers in the District of Columbia will be increased based on the percentage change in the price index for the preceding year. Annuities with a commencing date on or before September 1 of the year will receive a pro rata increase. The annual cost-of-living adjustment for public-school teachers in the District of Columbia will be increased based on the percentage change in the price index for the preceding year. Annuities with a commencing date on or before September 1 of the year will receive a pro rata increase adjusted to the nearest \1/10\ of 1 per centum. Subtitle C--Judges' Contribution

SEC. 221. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION.

(a) Amount of Withholding.--Amends section 11-1563(a), D.C. Code, to increase withholding to 4\1/2\ per centum for pay periods starting on or after October 1, 1996.

(b) Computation of Retirement Salary.--Amends section 11-1564(d)(1), D.C. Code, to adjust retirement salary contributions to 4\1/2\ per centum for services before October 1, 1996, and after October 1, 1996.

TITLE III--EFFECTIVE DATE

SEC. 301. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The amendments made by this Act will be effective on October 1, 1996.
